qualities.label: Social-Interaction Preference
qualities.description: Person–social fit predicts satisfaction and retention.

response_scores.1: I really prefer to work completely on my own and avoid group interaction whenever possible.
response_scores.2: I’m okay chatting briefly, but I focus better when I’m mostly by myself.
response_scores.3: I can work alone or with others; it doesn’t make much difference to me.
response_scores.4: I get energy from small-team collaboration and like bouncing ideas off teammates.
response_scores.5: Put me where I’m constantly talking with the public or a big group—that’s where I thrive!

key_research.paraphrase: High-social fit boosts satisfaction; solitary‑preferring volunteers excel in independent roles.

qualities.direct_question: Do you prefer working alone, with teams, or somewhere in between?

reflection_scores.1: Working solo cataloging artifacts at the museum felt peaceful—I hardly spoke to anyone and loved it.

reflection_scores.3: At the soup kitchen I shifted between prepping alone and serving guests—either mode was fine.
reflection_scores.4: Building tiny homes with a four‑person crew was a blast; we riffed ideas all afternoon.
reflection_scores.5: Running the festival game booth, I thrived on greeting a new family every minute.

qualities.label: Autonomy Threshold
qualities.description: Matching preference for structure vs autonomy needs prevents disengagement or confusion.

response_scores.1: I need clear step-by-step instructions; open-ended tasks stress me out.
response_scores.2: I like guidance and periodic check-ins to stay on track.
response_scores.3: Some guidelines are helpful, but I’m comfortable filling in gaps.
response_scores.4: Give me the goal and I’ll figure out how to get there.
response_scores.5: I love total freedom—just point me at the problem and let me run with it.

key_research.paraphrase: High-social fit boosts satisfaction; solitary‑preferring volunteers excel in independent roles.
Autonomy seekers thrive in loosely scripted projects; structure seekers prefer detailed SOPs.

qualities.direct_question: How much freedom versus detailed direction do you prefer?

reflection_scores.1: At a donation sort I wasn’t given instructions and kept asking what to do next—very frustrating.
reflection_scores.2: Packing meal boxes came with a clear checklist and supervisor check‑ins—I liked the guidance.
reflection_scores.3: During a beach cleanup the plan was vague but we figured out zones ourselves and it worked.
reflection_scores.4: For the voter‑registration drive they shared the goal, then let us design scripts—super motivating.
reflection_scores.5: Coordinating the park rebuild, we finished early and improvised extra improvements on the spot.

qualities.label: Novelty Preference

response_scores.3: A balance of routine and new challenges keeps me engaged.
response_scores.4: I feel energized when every day looks a bit different.
response_scores.5: I seek out projects where I can invent creative solutions from scratch.

key_research.paraphrase: Autonomy seekers thrive in loosely scripted projects; structure seekers prefer detailed SOPs.
